moves.1. e4 c5 2. f4: exactly, what I would have played: steering at the Grand Prix Attack...
moves.14... Rae8: Be3 is not covered: Nf5 is imminent...
moves.15. Bf2 f5 16. Qc2: both players are fully developed: the game is on...
moves.16... fxg4 17. Nxg4 Rxf4 18. Bg3: after the game, White reclaimed that this pawn sac was planned: but he didn't see the next move coming...
moves.18... Nxd4 19. cxd4: White cannot afford, to let the Knight live: after Qd1 - Ne2+ is a disaster - might follow Nf5...
moves.19... Bxd4+: securing three pawns, for the Knight...
moves.20. Kh1: after Bf2, White loses more tempo and Rf4 is off the hook: after Kh2, White runs the risk of more checks; the bottom row is safest for now...
moves.20... Rxf1+ 21. Rxf1 Nf5 22. Bf2: forced: square e3 has to be defended against Ne3...
moves.22... Qd6: another forcing move: introducing Ng3+: after also Be5, White gets in big trouble...
moves.23. Bxd4: so this move is also forced...
moves.23... Nxd4: and again, we meet this motif: Ne2 might be next...
moves.25. Rf3: not solving the issue, but forced...
moves.25... Ng3+ 26. Kg1: the only one: returning Ne2+ is useless...
moves.26... b5: Black has time for preparing d4: but first cover c4...
moves.27. Rf2: after d4, Rf3 is attacked: this might just work...
moves.27... a5: d4 won't work for now: Bb7 is not covered; so Black plays a silent move...
moves.28. Bf3: searching for play: this covers e2...
moves.28... Bc6: still pushing for d4: now, the LSB is covered...
moves.29. Ne4: Whites' first serious attacking break: after Nxe4, Bxe4, Rxe4, Nf6+, Kg7, Nxe4, Black loses material...
moves.30. Nxg3: Nf6+ is an option: but after Kf7, Nxe8+, Bxe8, there is no attack left...
moves.30... Qxg3+ 31. Rg2: White has things in order: for now...
moves.31... Qd6: just in time, to secure d5 and prevent Nf6+...
moves.32. Qd2: time for White, to start defending...
moves.32... Rd8: after d4, Bxc6, Qxc6, d4 is uncovered: so first this...
moves.33. Qe2: d4 is unstoppable, so White makes the best of it...
moves.33... d4 34. Kf2: no use is Bxc6, Qxc6: so all hands on Bf3...
moves.34... Bxf3 35. Kxf3: after Qxf3, Rf8, losing the Queen...
moves.36... Qe6+: also Re8 is winning, but I liked this better...
moves.37. Ne5: after Kxd4, Rd8+, White is running mate...
moves.37... Rf5: very useful move: also preventing Qh5!...
moves.38. Kxd4: forced: all else mates, after Qxe5...
moves.40. Qg4: trying to make play: but too incautious...
moves.40... Re3+ 41. Kc2 Qd3+ 42. Kc1 Re1+: White has to give the Queen: he complied out of respect...
